_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The T.G. Dairy, Orlando plant, processes fluid milk.   The facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant to maintain the proper temperature of fluid milk within the facility.  Anhydrous ammonia is an effective refrigerant that has been used for many years by most food processing facilities.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:   T.G. Dairy is committed to promoting safety for the plant, its employees and the surrounding area.  The facility is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard, Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.110 and EPA's Risk Management Program Title 40 CFR Part 68.  The purpose of these programs is to ensure that the refrigeration system is operated safely in order to prevent releases of ammonia from the system.  In addition, the programs serve to develop procedures to minimize releases in the event that they do occur and to outline appropriate emergency response steps to take in the event of a release.



Worst Case Release Scenario:  "Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration and the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration's Risk Management Guidelines were the primary sources used to develop the worst case release scenario.  The worst case release is one that is unlikely to occur.  The purpose of the worst case release analysis is to support a dialogue with the community on release prevention.  It is a conservative analysis and is not to serve as a rational basis for the actual emergency response planning.  The facility utilized RMP*Comp and MARPLOT for this scenario to determine toxic release endpoint and population data.





Alternative Case Release Scenario:  The alternative release scenario selected is one in which a relief valve lifts due to a pressure build up in the system.  EPA's "Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration and the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration's Risk Management Guidelines were the primary documents used to de

velop the alternative release scenario.  The alternative release scenario is one that is more likely to occur than the worst case release scenario.  The facility utilized RMP*Comp and MARPLOT for this scenario to calculate toxic release endpoint and population data.



Accidental Release Prevention Program:  As a part of the PSM program, T.G. Dairy has established numerous programs that serve to prevent accidental releases of ammonia.  The programs include:

Process Safety Information

Process Hazard Analysis

Operating Procedures

Training

Mechanical Integrity

Management of Change

Pre Startup Safety Review

Compliance Audits

Incident Investigation

Employee Participation

Hot Work Permits

Contractor Safety



Emergency Response Information:  As a part of the PSM Program, T.G. Dairy maintains an Emergency Response Plan that was prepared in order to improve responsiveness to an emergency incident, and to increase the reliability of actions taken during an incident.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, and notification of local emergency response agencies.  Training is conducted with each new employee and annually thereafter plant-wide.  Evacuation / response drills are conducted at least annually as well.



Five-Year Accident History:  T.G. Lee Foods, Inc. has had an excellent operating record over the last five years and have had no reportable releases.  Due to the stringent release prevention policies, all accidental releases have been minimized.  Incidents have been documented and analyzed to prevent future occurrences.            



In addition, T.G. Lee Foods, Inc. will continue to operate and maintain the system in accordance with IIAR Guidance and will continue to implement its OSHA PSM Program in conjunction with the Risk Management Program.
